note:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Accupril / gemfibrozil / Statins-Hmg-Coa Reductase Inhibitors / 
metformin
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
confusion, fever, shortness of breath
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
PICC placement (___)

 
History of Present Illness:
___ male with history of asthma, type 2 diabetes, CAD 
s/p
CABG ___, afib on apixaban, hypertension, and prostate
cancer who presented with acute onset shortness of breath and
altered mental status.

Prior to this he had been having difficulty urinating. His wife
called EMS ___ night because the patient was having 
difficulty
breathing. He was found in moderate respiratory distress and
placed on BiPAP with improvement. O2 sat has been above 90%.
Received nebs and steroids with EMS. Patient had been more
somnolent than usual since his shortness of breath started. His
wife does not think he has had fevers at home. Initial history
was limited due to the patient's somnolence; he is also hard of
hearing. He did awaken to voice. He denied chest pain or
abdominal pain.

In the ED, initial vitals: Yest 22:00 0 104.8 93 118/54 24 100%
bipap 

Exam notable for: somnolent but arousable to voice on arrival,
full neck range of motion. 

Labs notable for: WBC 6.8 (93% PMN), Hgb 10.1 (baseline appears
___, Na 128 (recent values in 140s), Cr 1.5 (baseline
creatinine about 1.0), glucose 144, INR 1.7, AST 46, LFTs
otherwise normal, VBG ___ lactate 3.1, trop negative x1,
BNP 594, flu negative, UA with mild hematuria

Imaging notable for:  
-CT head negative
-CT chest with no PNA, no PE, mild atelectasis
-CXR with vascular congestion

Pt given: 2g IV cefepime (10pm), 1500 IV vanco (11pm), 1g PR 
APAP
(10pm), 1L total LR

On reevaluation, patient was more awake and alert, able to
recount his history and symptoms (with some difficulty giving 
his
difficulty hearing). Weaned from BiPAP to NC. His only complaint
was that he was having difficulty urinating earlier. He does 
have
an enlarged prostate. Foley was placed. No headache, neck pain,
meningismus. ED did not feel LP was warranted.

Vitals prior to transfer: Today 01:50 0 99.8 75 113/62 19 96% 2L
NC 

Upon arrival to the floor, the patient is not able to interact.
His wife confirmed the above and added he was unsteady coming 
out
of bed today, fell and did not strike head. He normally uses a
walker when outside the house but was not using at the time. He
is normally A&Ox3, occasionally forgets minor things but is able
to converse and interact normally. Had been usual self (no
confusion, excess sleeping, etc.) until a few hours before EMS
called. Since symptoms started he has been hesitating before
speaking. When alert today he has been moving all limbs. Had no
chest pain, abdominal symptoms, bloody stool, rash. Last BM a 
few
days ago. No recent hospitalizations since CABG last year, saw
PCP and ___ within last few months. Per wife, med list
from most recent PCP visit should be correct. Does not have list
with patient.

 
Past Medical History:
 -POSSIBLE RETINAL TEAR  
 -ALLERGIC RHINITIS  
 -ANEMIA  
 -ASTHMA  
 -DIABETES TYPE II  
 -GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX  
 -HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA  
 -HYPERLIPIDEMIA  
 -HYPERTENSIVE HEART DISEASE  
 -PROSTATE CANCER  
 -SLEEP APNEA  
 -SPINAL STENOSIS  
 -URGE INCONTINENCE  
 -CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE s/p CABG ___ 
 -ATRIAL FIBRILLATION
 -MITRAL REGURGITATION 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION EXAM
===============
VITALS: 99.6 PO 112 / 62 R Lying 75 18 96 2 L 
GEN: somnolent, lying in bed, responsive to light shaking,
sweating that improved after turning off a very strong light
above his bed
NEURO: responds to shaking and sternal rub, able to follow 
simple
commands like moving limbs, not speaking, falls back asleep
easily
HEENT: pupils small but reactive equally and briskly, no scleral
icterus
NECK: JVP about a cm above clavicle at 45 degrees but augments 
to
earlobe with abdominal pressure
CV: RRR, no murmur
Lungs: clear anteriorly
Abd: soft, moderate distention, deep palpation does not seem to
cause pain 
GU: foley with clear yellow urine about 500 cc in bag
EXT: R>L ___ pitting edema (chronic per wife), DP palpable
bilaterally, feet warm
SKIN: no rash or obvious cuts

DISCHARGE EXAM
=============== 
VITALS: 24 HR Data (last updated ___ @ 450)
    Temp: 98.2 (Tm 99.1), BP: 136/77 (118-139/71-79), HR: 69 
(65-94), RR: 16 (___), O2 sat: 98% (95-98), O2 delivery: RA, 
Wt: 179.01 lb/81.2 kg  
GEN: well-appearing, sitting in bed eating breakfast
HEENT: pupils reactive equally and briskly, no scleral icterus
CV: RRR, nl S1/S2, no murmur/rubs/gallops
Lungs: mild bibasilar crackles, no appreciable wheezing
Abd: soft, moderate distention, no tenderness to deep palpation
NEURO: A&Ox3, strength and sensation grossly intact
EXT: R>L ___ pitting edema (chronic per wife), DP palpable 
bilaterally, feet warm
SKIN: no rash or obvious cuts

MICROBIOLOGY
=============
                           **FINAL REPORT ___

   Blood Culture, Routine (Final ___: 
      STREPTOCOCCUS MITIS/ORALIS.    FINAL SENSITIVITIES. 

                              SENSITIVITIES: MIC expressed in 
MCG/ML
                      
_________________________________________________________
                             STREPTOCOCCUS MITIS/ORALIS
                             |   
CEFTRIAXONE-----------  0.25 S
CLINDAMYCIN-----------<=0.25 S
ERYTHROMYCIN----------     4 R
PENICILLIN G----------   0.5 I
VANCOMYCIN------------<=0.12 S

 **FINAL REPORT ___

   URINE CULTURE (Final ___: 
      GRAM POSITIVE BACTERIA.    >100,000 CFU/mL. 
         Alpha hemolytic colonies consistent with alpha 
streptococcus or
         Lactobacillus sp. 

**FINAL REPORT ___

   MRSA SCREEN (Final ___:    No MRSA isolated.

        **FINAL REPORT ___

   GRAM STAIN (Final ___: 
      >25 PMNs and >10 epithelial cells/100X field. 
      Gram stain indicates extensive contamination with upper 
respiratory
      secretions. Bacterial culture results are invalid. 

IMAGING
========
EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP) ___

FINDINGS:    
Lung volumes are low with bibasilar atelectasis.  Evaluation of 
the heart size is limited in the setting of low lung volumes, 
however does not appear significantly enlarged.  There is 
pulmonary vascular congestion without frank pulmonary edema.  A 
small more focal opacity adjacent to the left hilum may 
represent a engorged pulmonary vasculature and overlying 
external artifact, however an early pneumonia is difficult to 
exclude.  No large pleural effusion.  No pneumothorax.  Median 
sternotomy wires are present. 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Low lung volumes with pulmonary vascular congestion. No frank 
pulmonary 
edema. 
2. Small more focal opacity adjacent to the left hilum may 
represent engorged pulmonary vasculature and overlying external 
artifact, however early pneumonia is difficult to exclude.

EXAMINATION:  CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST Q111 CT HEAD (___)
  
FINDINGS:  
There is no evidence of infarction, hemorrhage, edema, or mass.  
There is 
prominence of the ventricles and sulci, as expected for a.  
Subcortical and periventricular white matter hypodensities are 
nonspecific, however likely represent sequela of chronic small 
vessel ischemic disease.  There are atherosclerotic 
calcifications in the bilateral cavernous carotids and 
vertebral arteries. There is no evidence of fracture.  There is 
mild mucosal thickening in the ethmoid air cells.  The 
visualized portion of the remainder of the paranasal sinuses, 
mastoid air cells, and middle ear cavities are clear.  The 
visualized portion of the orbits are unremarkable. 
IMPRESSION:   
No evidence of mass, hemorrhage or infarction.

EXAMINATION:  CTA CHEST WITH CONTRAST (___)
  
FINDINGS:   
HEART AND VASCULATURE: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified 
to the 
subsegmental level without filling defect to indicate a 
pulmonary embolus, 
with evaluation of the lingular segmental and subsegmental 
branches slightly limited by respiratory motion in that area.  
The thoracic aorta is normal in caliber without evidence of 
dissection or intramural hematoma.  The heart is mildly 
enlarged.  Patient is status post CABG.  There are diffuse 
coronary artery calcifications in the native coronary arteries.  
No pericardial effusion is seen.  Median sternotomy wires are 
noted. 
 
AXILLA, HILA, AND MEDIASTINUM: No axillary, mediastinal, or 
hilar lymphadenopathy is present.  No mediastinal mass. 
  
PLEURAL SPACES: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. 
  
LUNGS/AIRWAYS: There are small homogeneously enhancing 
consolidations at the bilateral lung bases consistent with 
atelectasis.  The airways are patent to the level of the 
segmental bronchi bilaterally. 
  
BASE OF NECK: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show 
no abnormality. 
  
ABDOMEN: Few subcentimeter hypodensities in the liver are 
incompletely 
characterized, however statistically likely represent hepatic 
cysts or biliary hamartomas. Included portion of the upper 
abdomen is unremarkable. 
  
BONES: There are degenerative changes in the thoracic spine.  No 
suspicious osseous abnormality is seen.? There is no acute 
fracture. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality. 
2. Low lung volumes with mild bibasilar atelectasis. 

EEG on ___
IMPRESSION: This was an abnormal routine EEG showed a normal 
background due to absence of posterior dominant rhythm 
indicative of mild encephalopathy nonspecific as to etiology. 
Diffuse anteriorly predominant alpha and excessive beta activity 
can be seen with medication effect. There were no focal 
findings, epileptiform discharges, or electrographic seizures. 
  
TTE on ___
IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
mild regional systolic dysfunction most consistent with single 
vessel coronary artery disease (PDA distribution). No valvular 
pathology or pathologic flow identified.

EXAMINATION:  DX CHEST PORTABLE PICC LINE PLACEMENT (___)
IMPRESSION:   
Compared to chest radiographs, ___. 
Lungs are low in volume but clear of any focal abnormality.  
Pulmonary 
vasculature is borderline engorged, but heart size is normal and 
there is no pulmonary edema or pleural effusion.  No 
pneumothorax. Right PIC line ends in the region of the superior 
cavoatrial junction. 

  

 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT & PLAN: 
___ male with history of asthma, type 2 diabetes, CAD 
s/p CABG ___, afib on apixaban, hypertension, and prostate 
cancer (on lupron) who was admitted with somnolence and dyspnea, 
found to have high fever and hyponatremia w/ ___. Pt was 
empirically treated with abx, found to have strep mitis/oralis 
bacteremia with unclear source. Was narrowed to CTX and 
discharged with PICC for 4 weeks of treatment.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
======================
[ ] Continue CTX 2g q24h through ___ (for 4 week course)
[ ] Will need weekly CBC w/ diff, BUN, Cr, AST/ALT/TBili/ALP, 
CRP (per ID)
ALL LAB RESULTS SHOULD BE SENT TO:
ATTN: ___ CLINIC - FAX: ___
[ ] Last day of antibiotics is ___
[ ] Should be seen by dentistry in the setting of Strep viridans 
bacteremia w/ unclear source

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
# Fever
# Strep mitis/oralis bacteremia
Pt presented with AMS and fever to 104.8. Was empirically 
started on vanc/cefepime with subsequent improvement. TTE 
without vegetations; TEE and LP deferred per ID team. Blood cx 
grew Strep mitis/oralis. Was narrowed to CTX. Urine cx growing 
alpha hemolytic colonies; likely spillover from blood per ID. 
MRSA swab negative. Given severe initial presentation, it was 
decided by ID to treat empirically with 4 week course. PICC was 
placed and pt was discharged on CTX 2g q24h for 4 week course, 
set to end on ___. Pt has planned follow-up with outpt ID and 
will undergo weekly labs per their team.

# Encephalopathy
Pt presented with AMS and difficulty breathing, found to be 
febrile to 104.8 with labs notable for Na 128. CT head negative 
for stroke or bleed, is on anticoagulation, and had no 
significant afib burden on recent ziopatch. No inciting med 
changes. Encephalopathy likely multifactorial, with infection as 
major source (being treated w/ abx), as well as hyponatremia 
(resolved). Largely resolved after 24 hours of abx. No other 
clear source of AMS on work-up; TSH, B12, RPR, AM cortisol all 
wnl. Per wife, pt was back to baseline prior to discharge with 
plan to continue abx for 4 weeks as above.

# Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure
# Asthma
Pt presented with SOB and hypoxia. Thought to be multifactorial 
from worsened mental status, mild volume overload, and asthma. 
CTA negative for PE. No signs of COPD or significant pulm edema 
on CXR. Mild end-exp wheezes on exdam. Pt was continued on his 
home albuterol and Advair. He was diuresed with IV Lasix 
boluses. Was also given duonebs with improvement. Resumed home 
montelukast. 

# Acute on Chronic HFpEF
# Volume Overload
Pt has significant hx of CAD s/p 5vCABG. On lasix 40mg PO at 
home. Diuretics initially held i/s/o ___ on admission. Found to 
be volume overloaded on exam. Diuresed with IV lasix after ___ 
resolved. Discharged on home Lasix.

# Hyponatremia
# ___
Presented with Na 128 and Cr 1.5 (from baseline at 1). Urine Na 
<20. Given 1L LR total in the ED. Improved Na to 141 and Cr to 
1.2. Thought to be prerenal in setting of infection. Less c/f 
CHF, though volume overloaded on exam. ___ continued to improve 
and resolved prior to discharge. Pt was diuresed with IV Lasix 
later in course and was discharged on his home Lasix.

# LFT Abnormalities
LFTs were normal on admission. However, incr to ALT 68, AST 231, 
nl Alk Phos and TBili.after initiation of abx with 
hepatocellular pattern of injury. Likely drug-induced I/s/o high 
dose abx therapy. As regimen was narrowed, LFTs downtrended and 
were ALT 76, AST 118, and nl Alk Phos and TBili on discharge.

# Urinary Retention
# History of Prostate Cancer
Per chart review, pt has an enlarged prostate and has had issues 
with
urinary retention in past. He was continued on his home 
tamsulosin.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
=============== 
#Paroxysmal Atrial fibrillation: CHADSVASC 4. Was continued on 
home amiodorone. Apixaban was initially held i/s/o ___, and 
resumed at home dosing once resolved.
sinus rhythm. 
#CAD s/p CABG: Home ASA, ezetimibe.
#HTN: Initially held anti-HTN meds i/s/o encephalopathy. Was 
resumed on home amlodipine 5mg prior to discharge.
#T2DM: Diet controlled.
#GERD: Home omeprazole.

#CODE: full presumed (no prior ACP)
#CONTACT:

Phone Number: ___
Cell phone: ___
Can contact wife, ___ at ___

Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service

Discharge Diagnosis:
Streptococcus mitis/oralis blood stream infection

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent (hard of hearing)
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking part in your care here at ___!

Why was I admitted to the hospital?
- You were admitted for confusion and difficulty breathing, and 
were found to have bacteria in your blood.

What was done for me while I was in the hospital?
- You were given antibiotics to treat your infection.
- You were given a special IV to help you get the rest of your 
treatment at home.

What should I do when I leave the hospital?
-Please go to your follow up appointments as scheduled in the 
discharge papers.

- Please monitor for new/or worsening symptoms. If you do not 
feel like you are getting better or have any other concerns, 
please call your doctor to discuss or return to the emergency 
room.

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
